_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Seismic hazard identified in Section 7.4(d) and the external events analysis was conducted based on the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, 19 California Code of Regulation 2735.
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Terminal Emergency Shutdown System, Smart loading hose technology
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Operator surveillance and truck loader attendance during product transfer operations

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
California Accidental Release Prevention Program
Enterprise Products Operating LLC.
Bakersfield Terminal
RMP Executive Summary

The Bakersfield Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) storage facility.  The process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and Cal OSHA Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, Title 8 California Code of Regulations 5189 and 19 California Cod of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This is a RMP/CalARP Program Level 3 facility.

Enterprise Products Operating LLC recently acquired the facility from Coast Energy Group and is in the process of implementing the Enterprise Process Safety Management Systems.  The Bakersfield Terminal has a commitment to employee and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The prevention program is based on the requirements of 19 California Code of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program and includes the following:  Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor Evaluation, Contractor and Visitor Orientation, Pre-Job Start-Up Review, Mechanical Integrity, Code of Safe Work Practices (Hot Work Permit, Confined Space Entry, Control of Hazardous Energy), Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, and internal Compliance Audit.

Training includes employee responsibilities in the process safety management program, National Propane Gas Association - certified employee training program, hot work permit procedure, code of sa

fe work practices, and operating procedures.  All visitors entering the property must undergo a site safety orientation and check-in prior to each visit.  Planned changes to improve safety have been established based on compliance with the process safety management audits and revalidation of the process hazard analysis.  The last process hazard analysis revalidation was in May of 1999 and is scheduled for revalidation in the spring of 2004.

The Terminal receives, stores and distributes LPG and natural gasoline by rail cars and/or transport trucks.  The terminal has a number of storage tanks used for the receipt, storage and redelivery of gasoline and liquified petroleum gases.  The tanks are administratively controlled to hold LPG or natural gasoline at 85% maximum capacity, and are configured to store one or more of the various pruducts that can be handled by the terminal.  The facility is also capable of receiving a ProMix LPG product (a mixture of propane and butane) via a connected LPG pipeline.  The ProMix is stored for redelivery and shipment into either rail tank cars or tanker trucks.  

Enterprise Products Operating LLC maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies.  The Bakersfield Terminal has recently updated the facility's Hazardous Materials Business Plan and is on file with Kern County Environmental Health Department - Certified Unified Program Agency.  The facility maintains an air permit to operate with the San Joaquin Unified Air Pollution Control District.


In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate one of the emergency shutdown devices, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Bakersfield Police and Fire Departments.

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10 and 19 CCR 2735.4, this facility has not had an accidental release.  This information was verified by

the reviewing of records from the Kern County Environmental Health Department - Certified Unified Program Agency.

The worst-case release scenario for the terminal is calculated based upon the maximum amount of product contained in a supply or delivery rail car.  The alternative release scenario for this process is a hose rupture while pumping propane into an 18-wheel delivery truck.  Installed automatic shutoffs were assumed to fail, requiring a short delay before the terminal operator could activate a secondary remote emergency shutdown system.  Details on the worst case and alternate case scenarios are contiained in the appropriate sections of the RMP registration documents.
  
A preliminary seismic walkthrough was conducted by the precious owner to fulfill the requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, 19 CCR 2745.7 (q)(2).  The preliminary seismic walkthrough consisted of a visual inspection of the process piping and vessels above grade.  Structural integrity below grade was not inspected.  Walkthrough considerations included the mechanical integrity of pipe, pipe supports, vessels and vessel supports, welds, flanges, valves, pressure safety valves, signs of surface corrosion, pipe stress points, foundations, drainage direction fire control and interaction with other elements.

The reference used for this walkthrough were the following:

API Standard 570 Pressure Vessel Inspection Code:  Maintenance Inspection, Rating, Repair and Alteration.

Process Unlimited International, Inc., Engineered Safety Section, CalARP Seismic Assessment Procedure, April 12, 1999.

Uniform Building Code, 1997 Edition, International Conference of Building Officials.

Based on the document, Maps of Known Active Fault Near-Source Zones in California and Adjacent Portions of Nevada:  Uniform Building Code 1997, this facility resides outside the boundaries of the Near-Source Fault Zone.  Enterprise Products Operating conducted a safety and environmental assessm

ent to review compliance of the entire facility with all applicable regulations in January of 2008.  The assessment included a walk-through of the entire facility to again confirm the condition of above ground facilities.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise Products Operating LLC is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Enterprise Products is committed to the safe design, maintenance and operations of the Bakersfield LPG Terminal.  Enterprise considers and acuts upon action items  from Process Hazard Analyses, facility audits, and incident investigations when the recommendation can be shown to provide an expected improvement in facility safety.  Employees are also encouraged to evaluate the safety of the terminal and their job fjunctions as part of normal terminal operations, and to recommend safety improvements for consideration.  At the present time, there are no project planned for installation that would be installed primarily to improve the safety of  the terminal.
